hobby.message: What's your last origami fold say?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Just tired. Needed a break from the usual routines.
Took the drone out today, quick flight over the grid.
Blackouts messed with the connection—nothing serious but annoying.
Still, it clears my head, most days.
I’m alright. Needed to clear my head after work.
Did some FPV drone flying out by the old conveyor belts.
System blackout made it weird out there. Less surveillance, more interference.
Crowds have moved in lately, guess everyone's looking for a gap.
Hobby like mine, you notice who’s watching.
Doing okay. Took my drone out after shift, like I usually do.
I fly FPV in the industrial zones—less crowded, no tourists.
Since the system crash, you get more random signals in the air.
Had a near-miss with some rogue flier by Tower 9.
Used to be just me out there. Now it’s… different.
But it helps me stay balanced, you know?
Honestly, it’s better now that I’ve flown my drone tonight.
FPV freestyle, mostly in blackout districts. Feels like freedom for a few minutes.
The inheritance riddles have pulled new people into the off-grid zones.
Almost collided with someone tracking riddle clues last time. They didn’t respond over open channel.
The blackout always cuts feed mid-flight, but it keeps things interesting.
I’ve started manually logging flight data—can’t trust city memory anymore.
My brother used to think drone flying was pointless. Now, I get why he disappeared.
I’m alright, just wiped after flying tonight. That’s my thing—FPV drones, freestyle.
I go out to the dead sectors, especially since the blackout shifted control to neighborhoods.
It’s one of the last ways to be off-grid for a bit. No BCI pings, less tracking.
Since Halden’s inheritance protocols, you get these random aerial encounters—everyone’s looking for clues or just breathing.
Last weekend, another drone synced up with mine, no comms, like a silent pact.
Sometimes I wonder if it’s Council or Directorate watching, or just people like me dodging the system.
Manual logs only now—the public feeds are useless since the data shocks.
My brother vanished in a BCI audit two years ago. I get why he wanted out, especially now.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still flying when I can.
Been harder with power cuts and random checks lately.
Crowds show up less around the old factory zone now.
Never take the same route in or out.
City’s changing. I just adapt.
Yeah, the drones still work for clearing my head.
Not as smooth since the neighborhood grid changes and blackout.
Lost video feed last week, had to fly completely manual.
Other pilots keep their distance now. Too many eyes.
Noticed a few curious observers after the broadcast.
Sticking to empty sectors keeps things simple.
Yeah, still helps. Nothing clears noise like a clean FPV run.
Since the blackout, signals get weird—sometimes lose connection near Tower 9.
More pilots out lately, probably chasing those AI riddles.
People are less likely to report you now. System’s distracted.
Tried flying during the blackout—almost pure silence out there.
Battery swapping’s tougher. Assemblies lock up power.
Still, catching wind through broken scaffolds feels like a win.
Honestly, nothing else compares. Freestyle is pure focus, pure drift.
The system glitch after Halden’s death made flying unpredictable. Lost signal mid-trick.
Had to repair my quad myself—no way I was logging a request.
Huge turnout at Tower 9. Saw pilots mapping for the inheritance protocol clue.
Nobody trusts automatic replays now, everything’s shifted to manual backups.
Night flights are safer—no BCI pings in blackout zones.
Met a few regulars, but we keep it loose. No names, just flight paths.
Craziest bit: one night, two drones mirrored me perfectly through broken lights.
Definitely. FPV is more than a hobby—it’s control when everything else is chaos.
Started when BCI first rolled out, needed somewhere to disappear for a while.
After Halden died, blackout gave us total silence—first real freedom in years.
City infrastructure breaking means we fly deeper, further. Nobody tracks low-power quads.
Some of us run ghost firmware, keep our flights off any official logs.
At Tower 9, I caught another pilot mid-riddle hunt. Neither of us said a word.
Last week, lost my feed for five minutes—heart racing, but strangely peaceful.
Energy quotas make battery swaps tricky, so we share cells off-books now.
Feels like—finally—a bit of space for people who live off-grid, at least until the Council resets everything.
